marker.name: Alexander gardens
marker.infowindow: Small park with a bowling green and play area.

marker.name: Alexander gardens play area
marker.infowindow:
All ages

This small play area has a playhouse, swings and springers for the under 6's and a climb net for older children.

marker.name: Arbury Court play area
marker.infowindow:
All ages

Next to the shopping centre, this small green area has a tower, swings and trim trail for small children and a modular climb unit, nest swing and rotating items for older children.

marker.name: Arbury Town park
marker.infowindow: Large receation space. Situation behind the Arbury Community Centre on Campkin Road with a car park.

marker.name: The Backs
marker.infowindow: The Cambridge Backs is a stretch of reclaimed land, which runs along the back of the riverside colleges. It provides stunning views throughout the year, and is covered with a blanket of daffodils and crocuses during the spring.

marker.name: Barnwell East local nature reserve
marker.infowindow:
Barnwell East has a circular path around the reserve, providing an excellent walk at any time of year.

Located East of Barnwell Rd or turn left off Coldhams Lane into Nuttings Rd Cul de Sac. Entrances on Uphall Rd and Barnwell Rd.

marker.name: Barnwell West local nature reserve
marker.infowindow:
Barnwell West provides an important wildlife corridor along Coldham’s Brook and is used by a variety of birds including Kingfishers and Nightingales.

Entrances on Barnwell Rd, Coldham’s Common and Galfrid Rd.

marker.name: Bramblefields local nature reserve
marker.infowindow:
Bramblefields provides an idyllic haven in the midst of a residential area with grassland, scrub and a pond. Along with its importance for birds, especially Song Thrushes, it is a brilliant site for families to visit.

Entrances on Discovery Way, Pippin Drive, Laxton Way, Ribston Way and Long Reach Rd.

marker.name: Brooks road play area
marker.infowindow: Green space with an all ages children's playground with springys, a slide and swings.

marker.name: Byron's Pool local nature reserve
marker.infowindow:
Byron's Pool was named after Lord Byron who used to swim at the weir pool where Kingfishers and Grey Wagtails can be seen.

The site also contains a number of small ponds.

Entrance from Car park off Grantchester Rd.

marker.name: Cambridge University botanic garden
marker.infowindow: This tranquil large garden has a collection of over 10,000 labelled plant species in beautifully landscaped settings, including rock garden, lake, glasshouses, winter garden, woodland walk, and nine national collections.

marker.name: Castle Hill
marker.infowindow: Although there are no ruins to be seen on Castle Hill, this grassy mound offers an expansive view over the roof tops of the town and surrounding countryside. On a clear day it is possible to see Ely Cathedral to the north.

marker.name: Cherry Hinton Hall Park
marker.infowindow:
Cherry Hinton Hall came into our ownership after the second world war and has been developed over the years into a very attractive park set amongst mature trees.

The natural area of park contains a lake with a collection of ornamental wild fowl which are always eager to be fed.

marker.name: Cherry Hinton Hall Park playground
marker.infowindow:
A very popular feature of the play area is the aerial runway along with climbers, group swing, springers, slide, tower unit, disabled kit and space net. There is also a small play area for the very young children.

There are two small paddling pools, one of which is specifically aimed at very young toddlers.

marker.name: Cherry Hinton recreation ground
marker.infowindow: Large recreation ground with two football pitches and a play area.

marker.name: Cherry Hinton recreation ground playground
marker.infowindow: Climbling frame, skateboard ramp, swings and a slide.

marker.name: Chesterton Recreation Ground
marker.infowindow: Two pitches and a children's playground.

marker.name: Chesterton Recreation Ground children's playground
marker.infowindow: This playground has a climber for under six year olds, swings, springys, a skate ramp for over sevens, mobilus, and climber swings.

marker.name: Chestnut Grove playground
marker.infowindow: Small green area with 3-11 play area with a climber, swings, and saw saw.

marker.name: Christ's College Fellows' Garden
marker.infowindow: This beautiful garden has been described as one of the glories of Cambridge. The college is situated in the busiest part of the city, and to step through the gates of Christ’s is to enter an alternative world of stillness and tranquillity.

marker.name: Christ's Pieces
marker.infowindow:
Situated in the city centre, bordered by the bus station, Christ's College, Emmanuel Road and King Street.

It has tree lined avenues, a Diana, Princess of Wales, rose garden, toilets with disabled facilities, refreshment kiosk and four free tennis courts.

marker.name: Christ's Pieces playground
marker.infowindow: Situated next to the tennis courts, this is for under 6's with swings, climber, springys, and graphics.

marker.name: Clare College Gardens
marker.infowindow: A fine example of a 20th Century English garden with old yews and chestnuts, swamp cypress, a gnarled Judas tree, and an old stonewall.

marker.name: Coe Fen (Laundress Green)
marker.infowindow:
South of Silver Street is Laundress Green (as here laundry would be stretched out to dry and bleach in the sun).

Punts can be hired for taking up river through the Meadows to Grantchester, or down stream past The Backs to Jesus Lock.

marker.name: Coldham's Common
marker.infowindow:
A sizable block of common land near the heart of Cambridge. Parts of it are grazed by cattle.

It has six full size football pitches, two junior football, one gaelic football and one american football pitch. All can be hired through Abbey Pool.

marker.name: Coldham's Common children's play area
marker.infowindow: For older children and located by Abbey Pool. It has a ball court and swings.

marker.name: Coleridge Park
marker.infowindow: This park has a football field, tennis courts and a children's playground.

marker.name: Coleridge Park playground
marker.infowindow: For younger children there are swings, a springy and a tower slide.7-13 Modular climbing, rotating kit .

marker.name: Ditton Fields Recreation Ground
marker.infowindow: Small green area with a basketball court.

marker.name: Donkey Common
marker.infowindow:
Alongside Gonville Place, with the Kelsey Kerridge/Parkside Pools sports complex, Queen Anne Terrace car park, skating ramps and YMCA.

During World War II there were temporary huts on the common and after the war they were used for temporary housing.

marker.name: Dudley Road recreation ground
marker.infowindow: Small green area with 3-13 play area with a skateramp, modular unit, swings, spinning unit and springys.

marker.name: Emmanuel College Gardens
marker.infowindow: Some of the finest within any Cambridge college. Has a massive copper beech, a 200-year oriental plane, and a small oak.

marker.name: Empty Common
marker.infowindow: Between the Nuffield (Evelyn) Hospital and the Government Offices site. Hobson's Brook runs along the east side.

marker.name: Flower Street play area
marker.infowindow:
All ages

Has swings and a cabin slide.

marker.name: Grantchester Meadows
marker.infowindow: These renowned meadows to the south of the city can be reached by walking across Lammas Land by the River Cam along a residential road called Grantchester Meadows.

marker.name: Green End Road recreation ground
marker.infowindow: For younger children there is a town climber and springys, for older children a runway, climbing net, swings and a youth shelter.

marker.name: Gunhild Close play area
marker.infowindow: This small green area has a slide, swings, springys, a modular unit and timber goals.

marker.name: Histon Road recreation ground
marker.infowindow: Small green area with climber, swings and springys for younger children and a runway, futball goals, modular climber and rest swing for older children.

marker.name: Holbrook Road Recreation Ground
marker.infowindow: This large green space has a climber, goal end and springys.

marker.name: Jesus Green
marker.infowindow:
Situated to the North of the City centre, Jesus Green is bordered by the River Cam, Victoria Avenue and Jesus College.

Divided by avenues of London Plane and Horse Chestnut trees, it is primarily an area of open parkland grass, offering informal and formal outdoor sports.

marker.name: Jesus Green Children's Playground
marker.infowindow: This fenced play area caters for children of all ages. Has a wooden railway engine, a mini roundabout, spring tractor, cradle seat swings, and agility climber, group swing and slide as well as a small picnic area.

marker.name: Kings Hedges Recreation ground
marker.infowindow: Large green space, built with housing around it facing in, and bike paths to provide through routes.

marker.name: Lammas Land
marker.infowindow:
Located to the South West of the City about half a mile from the centre, it is bordered by Fen Causeway and Newnham Road.

A very popular park in the summer primarily because of its paddling pool and large play area. There are large areas of mown grass which are ideal for picnics and sun bathing.

marker.name: Lammas Land play area
marker.infowindow:
Lammas Land play area has a wide range of play equipment caters for all ages of children. For young children there are springys and toner units, for older children a space net, climbers, swings, and a toner climber.

It is close to a large shallow paddling pool which is ideal for younger children.

marker.name: Lichfield Road play area
marker.infowindow: Caters for all ages of children with swings, springys and climbing unit.

marker.name: Limekiln Close and West Pit local nature reserve
marker.infowindow:
The undulating terrain of Limekiln Close and West Pit reserve are old quarries.

Access to both sites has recently been improved with the installation of more steps. Entrances off Fulbourn Rd via Ainsdale and Limekiln Rd. West Pit LNR is best accessed from the car park on the top of Limekiln Rd.

marker.name: Logan's Meadow local nature reserve
marker.infowindow:
Logan's Meadow is an oasis for nature within a recently developed area of the city. Previously used by Otters, the reserve is re-creating their favoured habitat.

It has a circular path and benches along the banks of the river. Entrance off Logans Way

marker.name: Midsummer common
marker.infowindow:
Home to the annual Midsummer Fair, one of the longest-established fairs in England, bonfire night and the Strawberry Fair.

Former names include Midsummer Green, Greencoft and Butts Green. The common is naturally grazed by a herd of bulls between April and October.

marker.name: Mill Road Cemetery
marker.infowindow: Like many urban cemeteries, this 15 acre site is now recognised as a valuable historical resource, containing the biography of a whole community. Built in 1848, on what was then the edge of the town, it is now listed by English Heritage.

marker.name: Nightingale Park
marker.infowindow: Large park with four pitches, play area and a bowling green.

marker.name: Nightingale Park play area
marker.infowindow: For younger children there's a springy, climber, slide and spinner. For older children, a runway, swings, spica, and rotating unit.

marker.name: Nine Wells local nature reserve
marker.infowindow:
Nine Wells contains several chalk springs, which form the source of the Hobson Conduit.

Located south of Addenbrookes Hospital this site is not accessible by car. Access via footpath from Granham’s Rd or via permissive paths from Foster Rd or Granham’s Rd.

marker.name: Nuns Way recreation ground
marker.infowindow: Two football pitches and a play area.

marker.name: Nuns Way recreation ground playground
marker.infowindow: This play area with sand play and a climber for small children and high tomers, high nets, spinners and running for big children.

marker.name: Paradise reserve
marker.infowindow:
On the northern bank of the Cam is a fragment of semi-natural habitat that used to be common.

Access is via Lammas Land Car Park and Owlstone Rd.

marker.name: Parkers Piece
marker.infowindow:
One of the best known open spaces in Cambridge, bordered by Park Terrace, Regent Terrace, Parkside and Gonville Place.

Derives from cook Edward Parker who owned it as grazing land. Now used for both formal and informal recreation and sporting activities.

marker.name: Pembroke college garden
marker.infowindow:
A beautiful garden with several courts and an orchard containing a small duck pond.

More information

marker.name: Peterhouse garden
marker.infowindow:
Peterhouse has the largest on-site gardens of any college.

The Deer Park resembles a well-kept meadow. The Scholars' Garden plays host to croquet in the summer.

marker.name: Petersfield
marker.infowindow: Small park next to Zion Baptist Chapel and surrounded by mature trees and shrub beds.

marker.name: Petersfield play area
marker.infowindow: Has swings and springys.

marker.name: Peverel Road play area
marker.infowindow: This small green space has a springy, climber and swings.

marker.name: Queen's green
marker.infowindow: The area between Queens' College and Queen's Road, separated from the College by an old branch of the river.

marker.name: Ravensworth Gardens play area
marker.infowindow: This play area is situated at the end of Ravensworth Gardens and is suitable for younger children and consists of mostly equipment for toddlers such as springys and swings.

marker.name: Riley Way play area
marker.infowindow: This play area is suitable for younger children and consists of mostly equipment for toddlers such as springys and a slide.

marker.name: Romsey Recreation Ground
marker.infowindow: Public park, with children's playground. Also known as Vinery Road Park.

marker.name: St. Albans Road Recreation ground
marker.infowindow: Has a football pitch, basketball, skateboard ramp and children's play equipment.

marker.name: St. Albans Road Recreation ground playground
marker.infowindow: The play area has a springy, trin trail, swings, runway, MUGA and mobilns.

marker.name: St Matthew's Piece
marker.infowindow: Common-land park since 1898.

marker.name: St Matthew's Piece play area
marker.infowindow: For young children there are springys, swings and a climber. For older children a modular climber, nest swing and a basketball half court.

marker.name: St Thomas Square play area
marker.infowindow: This small green space has a see saw, swings and a slide.

marker.name: Scotland Road recreation ground
marker.infowindow: Small green area with a springy climber and swings for younger children and a basketball half court for older children.

marker.name: Shelly Row play area
marker.infowindow: This small green space has a springy, swing and tot town climber for small children.

marker.name: Sheep's Green
marker.infowindow:
Situated to the West of Coe Fen, along the West bank of the River Cam and is grazed in the summer by cattle and at times horses.

Sheeps Green has an outdoor learner pool which is open in the Summer months.

marker.name: Stourbridge Common
marker.infowindow:
Large common that was once the site of Stourbridge Fair.

More information

marker.name: Stourbridge Common play area
marker.infowindow: The all ages play area has springys, a modular climber, runway and rotating unit.

marker.name: Tenby Close play area
marker.infowindow: This all ages play area has springys and a slide.

marker.name: Tennison Road / Ravensworth Gardens play area
marker.infowindow: This play area is located on a roof garden and is suitable for older children. There is a tower unit, swings and a springy, for younger children springys and swings.

marker.name: "The Pulley" park
marker.infowindow: Part of Kings Hedges recreation ground, this play area has lots of children's play equipment - swings, modular climbers, springys, trim trail, goals, sliders - for all ages and a learner pool.

marker.name: Thorpe Way / Fison Road play area
marker.infowindow: This large green area has a climber, swings and trim trail for younger children. For older children there are toners, rotating units, swings, a surf rider, runway and full ball court, fitness zone and climbing boulders.

marker.name: Trumpington recreation ground
marker.infowindow: This is a large open space surrounded by housing. The football pitch is open between September and May and there's a bowling green.

marker.name: Trumpington recreation ground play area
marker.infowindow: Large play area with a slide, swing and springys for young children and a runway, swings and rotating climbing unit for older children.

marker.name: Woodhead Drive play area
marker.infowindow: This small green space has a swing and a slide.
